TEXT: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Axis Bank conference call to discuss the Q4 and annual FY '18 results.
Axis Bank team is represented by Mr. Jairam Sridharan, Chief Financial Officer.
Participation in the conference call is by invitation only.
Axis Bank reserves the right to block access to any person to whom an invitation is not sent.
Unauthorized dissemination of the contents or the proceedings of the call is strictly prohibited, and prior explicit permission and written approval of Axis Bank is imperative.
(Operator Instructions) Please note that this conference is being recorded.
On behalf of Axis Bank, once again, I welcome all the participants to the Axis Bank Conference Call.
I now hand the conference over to Mr. Jairam Sridharan to brief all the guest on Q4 and annual FY '18 results.
Thank you, and over to you, sir.
Ladies and gentlemen, good evening.
I welcome you to our conference call for the presentation of the bank's performance for the fourth quarter and financial year 2018.
On this call with me is Mr. V. Srinivasan, Deputy Managing Director.
At the end of this presentation, the two of us would be glad to respond to your questions.
Earlier today, we shared 2 presentations on our website.
Our quarterly investor presentation, which is what we usually share as well as a special presentation called FY '19 Execution Strategy.
During the call, we do expect to refer to slides in both these presentation, so you might want to keep them handy.
Let me get straight to the key decision -- discussion point of the quarter, which is on asset quality.
You might want to refer to slides #48 through 55 in the earnings presentation for a discussion on asset quality.
In this quarter, we have significantly accelerated NPA recognition in parts of the book that had incipient weakness.
We have also applied the Feb 12 circular of RBI in a very conservative manner and have recognized a substantial portion of our restructured book as NPA.
Gross NPA formation in the quarter was INR 16,536 crores, of which INR 13,938 crores was from the corporate lending book.
59% of corporate slippages were from Power, Infra and Iron and Steel sectors.
Power sector NPA recognition has increased substantially in this quarter.
NPA ratio in this sector has gone up from around 4% at the beginning of the year to 44% now.
The slippages came predominantly from our previously disclosed stress book.
Of all corporate slippages in the quarter, 90% came from the BB & Below pool.
Rating downgrades into the standard BB & Below book were broadly similar to the last 5 quarters on a net basis at roughly INR 2,500 crores.
At this point of time, we are not changing our guidance and expectation on this rating downgrade cycle.
We will continue to watch how it goes.
But as of now, we continue to believe that there is another 1 to 2 quarters of the downgrade cycles still left.
We have continued to maintain a high provision coverage ratio on NPAs at 65%.
With the accelerated recognition that we have done, we believe that the NPA recognition phase of this credit cycle is now nearing completion.
The vulnerable book, which can be measured by BB & Below rated accounts, reduced by 44% during the quarter.
If you turn to Slide 51, which is where we have shown the long-term trend on this metric, you can see the BB & Below now stands at INR 8,994 crores or 1.8% of loans.
It is 1/4 of the 7.3% level that it was at 8 quarters ago.
I'd also like to state here that the bank's SME 2 portfolio at the end of the quarter was less than 0.5% of loans.
This is the lowest level of this ratio that we have had since the start of SME reporting in 2014.
Let me now move to our capital levels.
The bank's Tier 1 capital adequacy ratio at the end of FY '18 was 13.04% and a CET1 ratio of 11.68%.
Slide 59 in the presentation lays out the impact of various items on our Tier 1 ratio in FY '18.
If you look at our capital consumption trajectory over the last 10 years, you will see that the bank has grown loans at a CAGR of 22% over the period.
And in this period, we have consumed, on an average, 55 basis points of CET1 every year on a gross basis, i.e., without taking into account any capital raise.
We expect the next few years to be broadly similar in terms of CET1 consumption.
You might recall that as a part of our capital raise done towards the end of the last calendar year, we had issued INR 2,563 crores worth of warrants, which expire in June 2019.
If converted into equity, this would correspond to about 50 basis points of CET1 accretion at today's RWA levels.

When you put these facts together around the long-term capital consumption trajectory, the expected inflow, if warrants are exercised and the current levels of capital that we have, we believe that we have adequate growth capital to pursue growth opportunities for at least the next 2 years without the need to infuse fresh capital in this period.
Let me now discuss loan growth and the trends we are seeing across our business segments.
Banking system non-food credit growth continues to be steady and stood at 10.5% for the last fortnight of fiscal 2018, partly aided by the low base of last year.
Axis Bank's loan growth was healthy and stood at 18% Y-o-Y.
The retail loan book continues to grow strongly at 23% with significant diversification in portfolio mix.
If you refer to Slide 23, the growth in retail loans in Q4 was led by personal loans, credit cards and car loans that grew by 45%, 41% and 27%, respectively.
All our new engines of growth, like small business banking and education loans that we've been talking over the last multiple quarters, continue to see strong momentum.
Corporate loan growth was steady at 12%, same as that in Q3, with working capital loans continuing to grow strongly by 63% Y-o-Y.

In the corporate segment, we continue to focus on 4 elements: Reduce concentration risk; build a higher-rated lending book; increase the share of working capital loans and transaction banking revenues and prepare for a move towards deeper bond markets through our DCM franchise.

In line with these focus areas, you will notice on Slides 42 through 46 that the incremental sanctions that we have made have been, consistently with better-rated corporates, 86% to those rated A or better.
In our corporate book today, 77% of non-NPA outstanding exposure is to companies rated A or better, compared to 68% a year ago.

You'll also notice that the bank's exposure to our top 20 borrowers, as a percentage of Tier 1 capital, has been steadily declining and now stands at 121% at the end of this year, down from 287% at the end of financial year '11.
Our SME loan growth improved during the quarter and stood at 19% Y-o-Y, partly aided by a slightly suppressed phase in March '17.
The growth was broad-based as term loans and working capital both grew by 28% and 17% Y-o-Y, respectively.
Share of working capital to overall SME book currently stands at 77%.
And the focus here continues to be on building a high-rated book.
At present, 88% of non-NPA outstanding exposure in the SME book is to clients rated SME 3 or better.
Let me now move to a discussion on our retail franchise.
Our strong retail franchise continues to deliver.
The overall deposit growth for the bank during the fourth quarter stood at 9% Y-o-Y, influenced by the high base of last year.
On an average balance basis, deposit growth was 11% Y-o-Y.
CASA deposits on a daily average basis grew 18% Y-o-Y and comprised 46% of total deposits.
On a period-end basis, savings account and current account balances grew by 18% and 10% Y-o-Y, respectively.
On a daily average basis, they grew by 16% and 23%, respectively.
Overall, our CASA share in deposits stood at 54% at the end of the quarter.
CASA and retail term deposits continue to form a strong base and stood at 84% of total deposits, up by 281 basis points Y-o-Y.
Term deposits grew by 4% Y-o-Y, with retail term deposits growing faster at 11%, while wholesale term deposits declined by 7% Y-o-Y.
Slide 17 of the earnings presentation highlights the growth trend in retail fees over the last few years.
At the same time, retail fees have increasingly become more granular and annuity based.
The share of fees from cards has been steadily inching up from 26% at the end of first FY '13 to 38% at the end of FY '18.
Cards' fees grew strongly by 30% Y-o-Y in financial year '18.
Our internal customers on the deposit side continue to be the mainstay of the bank's strategy for sourcing, retail and lending customers.
71% of our new originations on lending in Q4 was from existing customers.
97% of the bank's credit cards and 74% of personal loan originations in the quarter were from existing customers of the bank.
51% of the overall sourcing happened through our branches.

Given this internal sourcing strategy of ours, we believe that branches remain essential for new customer acquisition and hence, continue to make investments in developing an extensive branch network.
We opened 114 branches during the quarter with a total network of now 3,703 branches.
However, the newer branches continue to get smaller in size.
Our leadership position in the digital payment space continues.
If you refer to Slide 29, you will notice that the bank has a strong market share across most digital payment products.
In the mobile banking space, the bank continues to rank among the top 3 players, both in terms of transaction value and volumes, as per the latest RBI data.
The bank had 4.5 million credit cards enforced at the end of the quarter, making us the 4th largest credit card issuer in the country, with a market share of 12%.
Credit card spends in the fourth quarter increased by 54% Y-o-Y to INR 13,167 crores, with debit cards growing by 1% Y-o-Y to INR 8,678 crores.
The bank is the second largest acquirer of point-of-sale terminals in the country with an installed base of over 0.49 million POS terminals.
We also continue to witness strong traction in adoption of digital channels by customers.
If you look at Slide 33 in the earnings presentation, you will see that 58% of the bank's active customers are digitally active.
42% of mobile banking customers prefer to use only the mobile app in interacting with the bank.
Mobile banking log-ins are now almost 6.5x that of Internet log-ins.
These are data points that make us increasingly more confident that dominance in the mobile space is a must-have for banks in the future.
If you flip over to Slide 35, these highlight our capabilities and strong positioning in the UPI space.
We are among the top 3 payment service providers in the NPCI's UPI ecosystem and currently have 11.5 million virtual payment addresses created across apps.
In the fourth quarter, Axis Bank processed 83 million UPI transactions, amongst the highest in the industry with a 17% market share.
We currently have 13.95 million unique registered customers.
Moving to the bank's earnings profile.
I request you to refer to Slides 12 through 15 of the earnings presentation.
NII for the quarter was flat at INR 4,730 crores, mainly on account of high slippages during the quarter.
For the full year FY '18, NII was up 3%.
The net interest margin for the quarter stood at 3.33%, with domestic net interest income at 3.59%.
Fee income growth for the fourth quarter was muted on a Y-o-Y basis but grew 9% Q-o-Q.
For the full year, fee growth was a tad better, with a healthy growth of 12% Y-o-Y and constituted 30% of operating revenue.
Retail fees continues to be an area of strength, with a robust growth of 22% and constituted 48% of the total fee income.
Corporate banking fees in FY '18 de-grew by 13% Y-o-Y.
Trading income for FY '18 stood at INR 1,617 crores, down 52% Y-o-Y.
Operating expenses growth for the quarter and for the full year stood at 14% and 15% Y-o-Y, respectively, moderating down from the highs of 21% Y-o-Y growth reported in FY '17.
Operating profit for FY '18 was down 11%, driven by lower growth in NII and treasury income.
Provisions and contingencies for the quarter increased by 178% Y-o-Y and 155% Q-o-Q to INR 7,180 crores.
For FY '18, the provisions and contingencies stood at INR 15,473 crores, higher than the INR 12,117 crores witnessed in FY '17.
For detailed provision breakup, you might want to refer to Slide 62.
Net profit for FY '18 declined by 93% Y-o-Y on account of the higher provisions that you saw in this quarter.
Return ratios have clearly seen moderation due to higher impact of provision costs.
Annualized ROE and ROA stood at 0.53% and 0.04%, respectively.
Finally, I'd like to discuss the bank's business outlook for FY '19.
For this, I would request you to refer to the presentation on FY '19 Execution Strategy.
In this presentation, we have tried to lay out the 4 vectors that the bank would like to focus on in terms of our strategy and what we would like to deliver in financial year '19.
If you look at Slide 2, you will see the 4 vectors of our strategy identified for this year; normalize credit costs, deliver profitable growth, enhance capabilities and invest for the future.
Our top vector of delivery this year will clearly be normalization of credit costs.
The accelerated recognition undertaken in this quarter will certainly help in that regard as will the high provision coverage levels we have at this point.
On incremental credit underwriting, we would like to continue shaping new originations in corporate lending towards lower risk businesses.

As we look towards the economic landscape in the country today, we feel increasingly confident about our ability to deliver growth in lending and not just on the retail side but also increasingly on the corporate side.

Clearly, there are signs of pickup in investment climate, the IBC based resolution processes are driving significant loan consolidation led demand and of course, as in prior years, the consumer class continues to be healthy.
So the opportunities for growth on the lending side are abundant.
Our capital levels make us confident that we can participate in the growth pick up as it plays out this year.
Needless to say, our deposit franchise needs to continue to deliver to help us fund the large loan growth that we see in front of us.
And we need to eke out more on the cost efficiency front.
These will be key focus areas for us on this second vector of delivery for FY '19, what we are calling deliver profitable growth.
The third vector we plan to focus on this year is enhancing capabilities.
In particular, we have identified 2 key focus areas for the year: A heightened focus on operational risk management capabilities and a talent and tech-driven reinvention of our corporate bank.
The fourth and final vector of delivery in FY '19 for us would be investing in the future.
There are 3 areas on this front that we have identified as clear differentiators of the bank that require continued investment; digital capabilities, analytics and our subsidiaries.
So that, in a nutshell, is a summary of what we plan to execute on and what we hope to deliver in terms of strategy in FY '19.
In terms of financial outcomes, our outlook for FY '19 is broadly as follows.
We expect new NPA formation to reduce quite significantly from FY '18 levels.
We are, at this point of time, continuing to look for credit cost normalization by second half of this coming year.
We will continue to watch the environment, particularly in terms of the resolution space to update that as necessary.
We expect loan growth in the high-teens to 20%.
And as I said before, we expect growth in both the retail and the corporate segments in this year.
We expect CASA growth in the high-teens.
We expect margins to be steady around FY '18 levels, unlike what has happened in the last 2 years where we've seen continued compression.
In the medium term, the bank expects to achieve an ROE upwards of 18%.
And in this year, you will see us take a big step forward towards that goal.
As I close, allow me to re-summarize some of the key themes.
With the accelerated recognition this quarter, the NPA recognition phase of this cycle, we believe, is nearly complete.
Our capital position continues to be strong, and we do not expect to need any infusion of capital for at least the next 2 years.
We expect strong growth opportunities next year on both the retail and the corporate segments.
We have clearly defined 4 vectors of delivery in terms of the bank's strategy for FY '19.
We now have, we believe, the capital, the growth appetite and the balance sheet strength to pursue substantial opportunities in the coming year.
With this, I come to the end of my comments, and at this point, Srini and I would be glad to take your questions.
(Operator Instructions) The first question is from the line of Mahrukh Adajania from IDFC Securities.
Just in terms of slippages, most of these slippages would be in the substandard category, because that will determine the provision going -- provisioning going ahead in the next year, right?
So just a clarity on that.
And then you say the credit costs will normalize in the second half this year, normalize to the -- to what percent level?
I mean, the old level or...?

So, Mahrukh, on your first question on what is the -- what's the level at which (inaudible) -- essentially I'm interpreting your first question as what is the amount of provisions you've made on the new slippages that have happened and is there a lot of, sort of, follow-on provisions to come on that pool, right?
If you see the provisions we have made this quarter, we've made INR 7,100 crores of provisions on a net basis, on a net increase of about INR 13,000 crores of NPA -- or net new slippages.
So clearly, we've provided upwards of 50% on the new slippages that have happened.
So no, I don't expect there to be a lot of follow-on provisions coming from this pool.
And on your second question, which is what does normalization look like?
We have continually talked to you all about our long-term credit history, about the last 15, 16 years.
And with the significant, sort of, credit costs in this quarter, you will see that that long-term trajectory, that 17-year trajectory, now reflects a long-term average of 110 basis points.
Now -- so somewhere in that 100, 110 range is what we believe is long-term normal.
And that's broadly what we mean when we say kind of return to normalization.
We'll move to next question, which is from the line of Nilang Mehta from HSBC Global Asset Management.
My question was more regarding management and with light of the 2019 execution strategy.
We've been hearing in different news stories on joining the corporate side of your bank in terms of management bandwidth.
If you could elaborate how do you expect to reinvent the corporate bank in light of these challenges?
And obviously, Shikha has been now cut short, how do you look to execute the strategy in terms of (inaudible) that you know, some uncertainty?
I'll take the 2nd-part of it a little bit and then Srini is going to -- Srini has a lot more to say on the corporate side.

One of the main reasons, Nilang, why we want to specifically talk about our FY '19 execution strategy is irrespective of leadership movements at the top of the house, we, as an organization, want to make it very clear where we stand as far as FY '19 is concerned and as the top leadership team, what we're all committing ourselves to in terms of delivering for FY '19.

And the 4 vectors that you see here are a collective commitment of the top management of the bank and are intended to give you, the investors, the confidence that there are some specific things that we are planning on delivering and working towards in FY '19.
And hence, sort of, the Shikha movement question doesn't necessarily have a kind of direct bearing on it because we all collectively committed to it.
On the corporate bank, Srini has thoughts.
I think the same thing.
I think what we are seeing is the top management is stable.
I think we had one change in the corporate bank side.
We have a new head of the corporate bank.
And other than that, the leadership is stable.
And across the bank as well as in the corporate bank, the teams are stable and as Jairam was saying that we're committed to delivering whatever we put out in terms of what we want to look for FY '19.
Srini, can you elaborate on your new hire on the corporate bank side and the (inaudible)?
Yes, we've hired Sundaresan who has joined us from Standard Chartered Bank.
And he joined us early April and Sidharth is moving on to -- moving outside the bank and he's currently on (inaudible).

Considering Standard Chartered was the only foreign bank which had massive NPAs on the corporate side, a corporate banking head from there seems to be going in the same direction where we were in the past, so it seems not very compelling actually.
Yes, that is your call, but I think we've done our due diligence.
We believe that's what I think is good for the bank.
The next question is from the line of Nilanjan Karfa from Jefferies.
Could we have a couple of data points?
I was just looking at the Slide 52 and if you can help me tally a couple of numbers.
So we started with gross NPA of, let's say, INR 250 billion and non-stress -- non-NPA is about INR 160 billion.
And I think last quarter you said it is about INR 50 billion of non-funded link to the BB & Below.
Could you tell me how these numbers stack up?
And additionally, for this -- for Q4 and Q3 as well, could we have the non-funded book, which is already -- whose funded partners has already become an NPA?
So the non-funded book in the non-NPA pool is now INR 2,400 crores, INR 24 billion, which was upwards of INR 50 billion last quarter, is now INR 24 billion.
Right.
And how much is now linked to -- who’s funded as like, is an NPA?
Do we have that number?
Sorry, say that again?
I mean the non-funded to those corporates who’s funded has already become NPL?
1 second, let me just grab that data.
It is roughly INR 1,000 crores.
And how was this in the December quarter?
I don't have that readily at hand.
And -- sorry, a second question, when you talk on SME 2, which is less than 0.5% of loans, do you mean the gross or the net loans?
Sorry, what is the difference, you mean provisioning?
Because provisioning is obviously a very large number, that's a very big change.
The denominator?
The denominator is gross customer assets.
Gross customer assets, not by...?
Sorry.
It's basically less than 0.5% of gross customer assets?
It is less than 0.5% of gross customer assets, that's right.
The next question is from the line of Vishal Goyal from UBS Securities.
So the question, again, is on 52.
Just any sense on what is the breakdown of this INR 9,000 crores, which is less INR 9,000 crores plus I think 2004 or (inaudible), a sectoral breakup?
It's total breakup, let's continue with the call, I'll see if I can get it.

And other thing is if you could just give us the movement of this particular watchlist, like from last quarter or wherever we left, because you used to give that very nice slide earlier where you showed the movement, like what was the total number last quarter?
And how that number basically is changed to now INR 9,000 crores?

Because it seems some deletion and some addition, and since you are saying 90% of the corporate NPA came from BB & Below, so either there is a INR 70 billion addition to the BB & Below pool, is that the right way of looking at it?
Right.
There's a lot of -- there's a lot of puts and takes that have happened here.
Firstly, remember that any upgrades that happen during any quarter, upgrades from NPAs, end up going back to fit in BB, right?
So all the upgrades that we've had during the course of the quarter end up going back there.
Our downgrades from BBB to BB in the course of the quarter were roughly similar to what you've seen in the last 4, 5 quarters, roughly INR 2,500 crores.
I think I mentioned that in the -- in my opening remarks.
So that hasn't changed.
What you're seeing is that of the total slippages, there wasn't -- and maybe this is -- we've not ever shared that number very clearly, but let me just, sort of, put it out there.
In the BB & Below pool, till last quarter, the accounts that were there in BB & Below, also a lot of them were SDR equity type of accounts, and they were investment instruments.
In SDR, the equity instruments that were also associated with them.
So when these accounts became NPA, all those investments became NPA as well.
That is about 10% of the total slippages in this quarter.
Roughly INR 1,400 crores is that SDR is fully related equity instrument.
So all of that -- and since there is nothing more of that nature left in the book, so the investment part of the BB book, which was INR 1,400 crores last quarter, is near 0 now.
So that 10% comes from there.
And then, there is some sort of -- and then there is about INR 10,000 crores of slippages from the opening pool, which is about 90% of the total slippages.
That is, sort of, INR 10,000 crores.
And there is some upgrades coming from NPA into here and INR 2,500 crores roughly give or take, INR 2,500 crores of net increase.
That's the sort of overall math of how we go from INR 16,000 crores to under INR 9,000 crores in the course of this quarter.
What (inaudible) the overall pool, the vulnerable pool, if you look at the sectoral distribution, 24% of this is Power, and another roughly 15% is Infra and another about 20% is Other Metals.
And the others, there is a longer tail.
Okay -- and sorry, one last question, if I can.
On this downgrade, which has been consistent at INR 25 billion roughly, how do you think about that?
So the large accounts, Vishal, a lot of the large accounts are, kind of -- are kind of down you see.
As we look at the downgrade pipeline, I have been saying this for the last 2 or 3 quarters, we thought that there are 4 more quarters of downgrades left and we said 3.
Now I think, there are 1 or 2 quarters of downgrades left.
Let's see how much.
There is a little bit less, but maybe not more than a quarter or 2.
But I wouldn't say that we're fully done with the downgrade cycle just yet.

As you might see in 1 of the slides, like in the Power sector, I think we've got this written somewhere, that in the Power sector, we have another about -- I mean, Power sector is about INR 10,000 crores.
And about 35% of it is -- so about INR 3,000 crores, INR 3,500 crores, is rated BBB.
I wouldn't be surprised if out of that INR 3,500 crores, you see some more downgrades into BB coming up over the next couple of quarters.
But I think, we have only about a quarter or 2 more left, Vishal, of the downgrade part of the cycle.
This quarter, for the first time, we actually saw a couple of accounts upgraded from BB out to BBB.
We haven't seen that in a long, long time.
So the fact that we saw the first upgrades is probably the sign of slowing down in the net downgrade cycle as well.
How much was the upgrade in the quarter, sorry, from the watchlist?
On the watchlist, nothing.
From the BB, it was below INR 1,000 crores, Vishal.
It's not a huge number, there were only 2 accounts.
But as I'm saying, we've not seen any in a long time.
So even these 2 accounts seem like something.
The next question is from the line of Roshan Chutkey from ICICI Prudential Asset Management.
Yes, so same question, again going back to the question that Vishal was asking.
So about INR 12,500 crores (inaudible) of standard (inaudible), right?
It is the rating migration downwards from BBB to BB.
I guess, to my calculation suggest about INR 5,400 crores of downgrade from -- or inflow into the BB & Below bucket?
So out of that, you need to take out whatever was recovery and upgrade is coming from below, not from above.
Right.
Recovery and upgrade -- how much went into this pool, into this bucket?
Roughly INR 2,500 crores, give or take.
Alright.
And so what is the total amount, which is spread into the BB & Below bucket outside of the upgrades or outside of the positive -- what is the negative flow into the BB & Below pool, altogether?
Maybe (inaudible) about INR 2,500 crores comes from top, about INR 2,500 crores comes from bottom and the rest is slippages.
I mean, give or take, this is broad math, but that's broadly it.
And can you just comment a little bit on the retail and SME slippages as well?
That seems to be a very high number.
Is it?
It's not actually like we've -- if you see numbers in detail, et cetera, they're pretty much at the same level, if not lower than what they were in the last quarter.
On a total basis, we're still looking at a sum of INR 491 crores, so -- in retail, and about INR 67 crores in SME.
So -- no they're not actually large numbers at all.
(Operator Instructions) The next question is from the line of Kunal Shah from Edelweiss securities.
So again coming back to the slippages outside of the corporate pool.
So that seems to be somewhere around INR 2,600-odd crores, maybe I think net slippages?
On a gross basis.
So INR 260,000 crores of maybe the ex-corporate loan book, it's like INR 2,600 crores of slippage, which is like 4%, kind of, run rate.
So that definitely seems to be higher than what has been there earlier.
So anything -- to read into it particularly in this particular quarter or any product segment, which are flowing in these kinds of slippages?
Kunal, you might recall that till a couple of quarters ago, we never disclosed the gross and net separately, particularly in the retail segment where we used to only talk about net.
The reason being that in retail, the delta between gross and net tends to be very, very high.
A large amount flows into gross and a very large amount actually gets recovered and so the net amount is always small.
Only in the last 2 quarters have we actually started disclosing this metric.
And you will see that what you're seeing now is fairly consistent.
The delta between gross and net is always high.
A lot of money actually does get recovered within the course of the period, in retail in particular.
And that's why you see this it's nothing out of the usual, the net slippage ratio in retail plus SME continues to be very much in control.
And if you can give the movement in means the ways we used to give it earlier, so maybe how much has been the interest income reversal in this quarter?
We filled that slide this quarter, didn't we?
See there is a meaningful reversal as you saw, I mean, you can imagine, we have INR 13,000 crores of net slippages.
So the delta is quite -- the delta is meaningful, I don't have the number readily at hand, but approximately.
No, because only thing is maybe today we are at -- in terms of the exit quarter, it is 3.33% and you highlighted NIMs to be somewhere around FY '17 level of 3.45%.
FY '18 level.
Yes, FY '18 level of 3.45%.
That again seems to be like hardly like 10, 15 bps kind of an improvement.
And I think in this particular quarter, interest reversal should have been much higher.
So are we guiding maybe structurally, otherwise x of maybe the slippages, NIMs are trending down?
No, actually x of slippages, NIMs, if anything, are trending up.
I don't think there is any structural pressure on NIM at this point.
The interest rate structure is not in terms of progression, and you're right.
The net -- the NIM compression would be about, give or take, about 10 basis points, for slippages, in the quarter, on a Q-o-Q basis.
So you're right.
There is that.
There is no signs to margin guidance.
So you can make your own assumption and it'll probably be better than ours.
And then lastly, in terms of fee income, so you have highlighted 2 reasons why retail fee income has been lower in this particular quarter.
But how are we looking at the overall fee income trend in FY '19?
And was this the only 2 reasons why retail has been like such a low fee income?
I mean, those are the 2 big reasons why we see in retail.
There are also some internal changes in terms of classifications.
But really that's -- those are the 2 main reasons.
But overall, on a fee basis, the fee broadly in line with -- or maybe just slightly below (inaudible) is what you should expect to see next year.
(Operator Instructions) The next question is from the line of Sreesankar Radhakrishnan from Prabhudas Lilladher.
A quick question.
You mentioned -- what is the exposure that this couldn't [allow in the] (inaudible) the presentation but on this -- outstanding in the watchlist, is it already in production?
Or is it still a work in progress that's soon to be completed?
The Power sector, the total exposure that we have is about -- a funded exposure that we have is INR 9,700 crores, and most of -- very little operatives under construction.
Most of the under construction stuff has now flipped.
The total Power sector NPA ratio in this quarter moved to 44%.
So clearly everything that was spread and whether there was a -- whether the project had been or not been completed, et cetera, has all gone to NPA side.

So -- but we do have some slightly more challenging projects here, but nothing as challenged as some of the stuff that we had in the past, where there were challenges on project completion, on PPAs, on [cold] blocks, et cetera.
So these are clearly the better of the lot.
But still, as I mentioned before, about 1/4 of them are in BB and about 1/3 of them are in BBB.
So it's not like these are blocking assets, but they -- but all the -- kind of the worst pool of this has now been recognized as NPA.
If I look at the [earlier] standard restructure plus your SGR and SME, et cetera, which probably was not in the NPA bucket, what as a percentage of your total advances, how much is it today?
Is it 1.8% what you are giving?
I mean, that is the math that we've shown on Slide 52, right.
We have looked at all the different kinds of vulnerability, netted them off against each other and then looked at them against customer asset.

Now if you want to look only at the restructuring dispensation, which is CDR, SGR, S4A, 5/25 and outside SDR if you just want to look at those and see how much are they as a proportion of customer asset, that sounds like 51, and that's 40 basis points.
40 bps.
If I can push you a last question, did you say that -- you mentioned that you [had] the first quarter and second quarter also, probably you did see enhanced credit cost.
So if you exit FY '19, say, the third and fourth quarter, by fourth quarter, where do you see your ROE and ROA going up?
We are not providing specific guidance on ROA, ROE.
It -- so much depends on what happens to the recovery and resolution environment.
The numbers can be widely off.
So we don't want to aggregate at this point.
The next question is from the line of Anand Laddha from HDFC Mutual Funds.
On the forward side, so I understand (inaudible) NPA this quarter happened here under-construction project.
Can you give any color on that?
What is the resolution for this project?
Is the bank management (inaudible) on the under-construction project?
I think the resolution mechanisms are on.
I think you have seen interest in some of these projects but clearly, there has been some ways if look at some of the projects which we have gone through a process.
Clearly, there are bits of different levels.
Clearly, there would be haircuts.
But there is possible resolution happening.
Actually, if you look at tariff rates, I think clearly tariff rates have moved up.
So to that extent, I think the interest is coming back, but there would be haircuts as far as the sector goes.
And clearly, a reasonable amount of resolution will happen.
Sir, my question is specifically on the construction project.
Do you think banks coming together, could a consortium of banks coming together and completing the under-construction project?
Or they will be left where they are?
Most of our projects -- the last projects are -- have completed under operation, possibly not running because of [goal] or PPA.
And second, sir, when you say second half, the slippages will normalize -- provision cost will normalize, and in the first half, the slippages will remain a little bit elevated.
Are you factoring in any resolution in the NPL in your assumption or...
Sir, I think when we talk of slippages, we are basically saying that from what you've seen over the last year, fresh slippages are going to be lower.
The resolution process, what it entails and what will happen is something which is getting increasingly difficult to predict.
Once we see the first 2 resolutions happen, I think the level of comfort will be there in terms of predicting the future growth.
And that's why I think that being a bit more conservative in saying the second half will possibly be the place where we'll see credit cost moderate.
Sir, you also mentioned your long-term slippage credit cost assumption is 110 basis points or 100 basis points.
But if I look at your loan book now, almost 50%, 60% of the loan book has become retail SME.
And there are -- the credit costs should be lower.
So that is why -- better historical of the loan book composition, so normalized credit cost will be significantly lower than 110 basis points.
That's a fair point.
I think what -- the data that we shared with you all is of unmodified data.
We are not adjusting it for business mix.
So on an unadjusted basis, the just simple arithmetic average of the last 17 years of credit cost comes out to 110 basis points.
You are right that if the business mix has shifted towards the lower credit cost businesses, then the adjusted expectation should be a little bit lower.
We will see as that plays out.
And lastly, you had just mentioned that the U.K.
subsidiary of yours has not been audited or audit has not been completed.
Can you give some color?
What is the size of the U.K.
subsidiary book, loan book?
Was there some part of it the watchlist also sitting in there also?
No, No, no.
No, it's a...
No, it's a subsidiary.
So none of our loans actually -- so there's a separate company, so it's -- and it's a fairly small one.
So it's not material from an overall perspective and essentially there is some sort of procedure or process we should do, which is not yet completed.
Sir, can you just give a breakup of your recovery and upgrade in this quarter?
It's almost like a large number, (inaudible).
Is there any lumpy element in that?
There were a couple of lumpy assets, but I can't tell you more than that.
There are 2 lumpy assets.
So what could be the proportion of that?
About half, let's say.
And the (inaudible) now also are very granular?
The next question is from the line of Manish Karwa from Deutsche Bank.
Jairam, you haven't given any details about your subsidiaries' performance this year.
If you can just share some of that, please?
At this point, we are not ready to -- I mean, if you saw our disclosure we have, today, declared the stand-alone financials.
One of our smaller subsidiaries, Axis Bank U.K., has not completed its audit process yet.
So today we did not announce the consolidated accounts.

We will do that over the course of the next few days, and then I'll share with you a lot more information and we will put up that on the website as well on the subsidiary's information that we usually share.
So you're not even sharing for Axis Capital, Axis Securities, et cetera?
We have not adopted all the subsidiary accounts.
It will be inappropriate for me to talk about it.
And just coming back to your NPA especially, the BB book, which is pending.
So you have like INR 9,000 crores, plus INR 2,400 crores of the nonfunded book, right?
And I think to an earlier question also you were to give the breakup of this book.
Would it be fair to assume that all the power exposure is a part of this book?
Not all the power exposure.
About -- this...
About 24% of this is power.
And 15% is Infra, and another 20% is, like, iron and metal.
And last question, you have a decent provision coverage, are you comfortable with this coverage ratio?
And should we assume that this is the kind of coverage ratio that you'll maintain?
We have been telling the same thing that we want to be in the 60% to 65% kind of band on provision coverage.
In this quarter, while we had a lot of new NPA formation, we continued -- or we decided to retain our provision coverage at the top end of our range, which is at 65%, which is what we have done.
Yes, we continue to be comfortable with that 60% to 65% range.

And lastly, as you were saying, you -- I mean, the general interpretation, is that the credit cost should be higher for the next 2 quarters, and thereafter it should go back to normalized credit costs, which you referred, those 200 basis points?
Fair?
I think that's fair.
So while there's -- while we wait for another question, there was a comment earlier about how much of our power exposure is under construction.
And I was just looking at one of the decks that we have -- in another prior quarter deck we had talked about this.
2 quarters ago, that proportion was about 13%.
So -- and now in the (inaudible) asset, it'll be a single-digit percentage you can figure out, under construction.
The next question is from the line of [Venkatesh Menjuri] from [Victor Asset Management].
I've got a couple of questions.
The first one, I'm referring to your presentation on FY '19 strategy.
So you've spoken about the reinvention of the corporate bank.
Can you just elaborate this, what is the new Axis Corporate Bank going to look like, what are the projects, what sort of profitability and stuff like that?
So I think we've been talking about this, clearly, in terms of 2 things.
One, in terms of the credit side itself, the loan mix in terms of working capital versus term loans, trying to change that mix.
It was term loan, and we're trying to make that more balanced.
That is one effort, which is on the Corporate Bank.

Second is in terms of credit income to noncredit income or what we call flow-based revenues and trying to make the flow-based revenues a higher proportion of the overall revenue pool of the Corporate Bank.
I think these 2 would be the -- and of course, third is digital.

I think we -- on the transaction, like we said, we made a lot of investments on the digital side to make sure the value proposition we have across all transaction banking products, whether it's trade, FX or cash management, I think how to integrate the platform to customers to sort of increase wallet share.
And I think that is the investment, which we have made, which is bearing fruit.
And I think that dimension that -- these are 3 dimensions across which we'll work on the Corporate Bank.
So is it right to say that you are, kind of, reducing your risk profile going towards working capital lending of lower segments here?
Sir, I think if you look at our sanctions, incremental sanctions, which we keep putting out, we always keep saying that more than 80% of the sanctions are to A-rated companies and above.
I think that will continue.
So does it mean that going forward, the ROEs in your corporate book more (inaudible) than you've seen in the past?
Not necessarily, right.
But I think if you look at overall revenue profile, the revenue profile can change, so the returns can still be quite (inaudible).

(inaudible) which is the CDs and why we are targeting because we truly believe that (inaudible) return on capital basis through the cycle, even with the kind of business that Srini is describing, smaller-ticket, working capital, flow base, lots of nonfunded income, fee income, liability side profile and the limited exposure on the project, the long-term lending side, and better-rated corporate, that profile of business through the cycle, that gives better credit risk return on capital.
You had mentioned you're looking at something like 18% ROE in the medium-term basis.
I guess 18% on the retail side is pretty much achievable.
But do you think this business can also achieve an 18% sort of ROE?
Between this and SME, yes.
That's one, the second one was slightly on a different topic not so much for corporate and the NPA topics in general going on.
On the insurance side, what are your thoughts on your tie-up with Max?
It's a couple of years for renewal, but your (inaudible) manufacturing versus thoughts of getting a stake in Max and going ahead with Max for a longer duration.
What are your thoughts on that?
Sure, [Venkatesh], if you look at our FY '19 execution strategy, that should tell you what our big focus areas are.

And we talked about the 4 vectors and in the short term, given everything that's going on in the bank, it is important for us to remain focused and try to do a few things and get them right in FY '19.
And that's why we have put out these 4 vectors.
And at this point of time, we are comfortable with where we are on our relationship with Max.
And I will sort of leave it at that.
Well, at some point, a few months ago, you were talking about manufacturing your own products.
Is that on the back burner right now?

Well, what I'd say is that this -- the deck on execution strategy appropriately covers, in the new context or where we are as a bank, what our key sort of focus areas are, and we want to remain focused on these and (inaudible).
The next question is from the line of M. B. Mahesh from Kotak Securities.
Very few basic questions.
One, Slide 52, when you look at Q3 FY data on the non-NPA book, the vulnerable pool, that number is actually lower.
[59 26] is lower than 51 20, which you have in BB & Below Advances.
And the same is true for 1Q.
Whereas if you look at the previous quarter's presentation, you had an additional INR 1,337 crores, which was in various restructuring dispensation as well.
No, that's a good catch.
I think it's a typo there.
I will need to correct that, sorry.
I think there's one digit on this that's a typo.
We will get that corrected and reuploaded.
Good catch.
And I think the same is true for 1Q FY '18.
So if you can just recheck that table.
When we just look at these numbers, because -- just trying to understand how can we...
Oh, yes, yes, yes.
You're right, you're right.
I think there is a typo in a couple of -- in these -- apologies.
That's a good catch on your part.
I'll fix that and we'll get that reuploaded tonight.
Second question, just a couple of very basic ones.
Provisions breakup, if you can just kind of give that.
And the third, provision-friendly security receipts that you have outstanding.
And the development that has happened during the course of the quarter, you increased savings interest rate on select quantum.
But we didn't see any response from some of the few large competition out there.
Was there any specific segment of business where you thought there was vulnerability?
And also why did you lose the bullion license from RBI?
Those are a lot of questions.
I'll try and sort of remember all of them.
The provision breakup you see on Slide 62, it's a regular slide we present.
So if you go there, you should see, sort of, quarter-on-quarter what the split is.
And your second question was on...
Security receipts outstanding.
Security receipts outstanding is INR 2,900 crores or something like that.
That hasn't changed in the last multiple quarters.
And your third question was what?
The savings account change and bullion license.
Savings account change, there is a particular segment in which -- this is not a defense thing, it's a playing offense thing.
There is one segment in which we were seeing and are seeing some opportunity.
And hence the move.
You -- if it works out, it works out.
If it doesn't work out, we'll be perfectly happy to go right back.
So we will see whether that particular segment will play -- is working out or not.
On...
Bullion.
On bullion, well, there is an annual review, which RBI conducts, and we are working with RBI to see what's best to do in terms of renewal of the license.
The next question is from the line of Krishnan ASV from SBICAP Securities.
Two questions that I have, one, I just wanted to understand is there an element of discretion in how much of recognition has gone through in the March quarter?
If yes, then why would you still have, say, INR 9,000-odd crores of BB, and why would you not recognize all of it in one go.
That's one.

Second question is, just your [ATM] cycle, hearing a lot of the investment people, who are now anchored on the fact that it's a no-credit cost business that you are building and hence, the next cycle credit cost will be significantly lower than what we have seen in the past.
Just wanted to understand what's been your strategy in building that retail growth.
Are we missing out any red flags?
Are we making the mistake that we might have made in the (inaudible) corporate lending?
Explain sir.
The first part of the question, if I understand it right is a, you might think we have gone a particular distance in terms of cleaning up the book.
Why not go "the whole way".
I mean, see, our thinking is we have done what we think is, sort of, appropriately conservative.
We have tried to be as conservative as we can, identify pockets where there was incipient stress and recognize it.
Within the limits of the regulatory guidelines, we think this is the most appropriate thing for us to do.
There is always going to be a line that you draw and there is always going to be some accounts just on the other side of that line.
So sort of a never-ending process of saying why did you stop here and not go -- not do 5 more accounts.
We did what we think is -- whatever we had, significant worries and risks -- where we saw that there is incipient stress building up, we took action.
Also, it's important to point out that a vast majority of the accounts that slipped in this quarter are not NPA with any other banks in the industry as the (inaudible).
So we are, in effect, the first bank to turn these -- to turn all these clients NPA.
So we have, in that sense, gone out, again we kind of forced this (inaudible) quite a bit in recognizing stressed pools and identifying them and marking them as NPAs.
So we've done basically the best that was regarded as appropriate.
Srini, you'd like to add something.
No, I think it's not fair to assume that any asset, which is BB rated is going to slip.
I think that is also not a fair assumption.
(inaudible) things like that, so you need to look at (inaudible) over the past few quarters, it does seem to imply that there is a new high standard.
The reason why it's called BB and below is because of (inaudible).
It makes sense for you, so make the appropriate assumption.
As we've said, BB is above 1.8% of customer assets right now.
Whether the -- eventually -- and it was -- it used to be, whatever, 7.5% or whatever it is.
If it -- is it going to eventually settle down at 1%?
Is it eventually going to settle down at 0.5%?
Is it going to settle down at 30 basis points?
I don't know where it is going to settle down.
And you should make your own, sort of, assumptions on that one.
Fair enough.
With the retail build out that happens, how are you making sure that you are...
Retail, see we've -- in retail, we have a portfolio mix, which is made up of many, many businesses.
So retail is not a single business entity.
There -- it's a (inaudible) of a lot of different businesses, all of which have very different risk-return profiles.
So you've got to actually constantly look at the risk-return, sort of, mix on that.
Our key thinking from a risk management perspective and retail has been sell to your deposit customers.
And that's why we gave so much emphasis on how much of our business came from existing customers.
We talk about it every quarter.
We show you the trend line.
And the design principle has been, the more unsecured the product, the greater the proportion it should come from existing clients of the bank.
And that's why you see businesses like credit card, we do 100% from existing clients of the bank or existing deposits by customers of the bank.
Similarly, a product like personal loans, you will see 75% of it coming from existing customers of the bank.
But a product like home loans, which is much -- it's at the other end of the spectrum, you will see maybe only 40% of it coming from existing customers of the bank.
But even there, the proportion will be at least 40%.
So -- but that's the full design principal.
If you first get a deposit account, see throughput information and identify clients who are a risk you want to take and then cross-sell to them.
That strategy has worked well for us so far.

And if you look -- if we look at the quarterly information that we get from credit bureaus, in terms of how retail customers of Axis Bank behave when compared with the same vintage retail customers of competition, we feel very good about the data we see in terms of the overall risk levels.
And so we feel very comfortable with the kind of portfolio that we're building right now.
Is that a great thing for you to include, given the kind of (inaudible) you have recognized in Q4 and you are indicating you may have (inaudible) in the first half '19?
Is there a rating agency interested here?
I mean, you look at the overall ratio of the bank, you look at the net NPA ratio at the end of quarter, you look at the CET1 ratio, it's roughly 11.68%.
You see the overall capital adequacy ratio at, whatever, 16-odd percent; the ratios are all absolutely spot on.
There is no -- and you look at the incipient stress book, which is pretty much the lowest it has been in a long, long time.
And as I mentioned in the call, an SME book, which is less than 50 basis points of loan and pretty much no large-ticket size loan left in the vulnerable pool.
So those are facts.

And we will, I mean, as a lending institution and as an institution that gets its borrowings rated, we will continue to always be in touch with rating agencies, but these facts are pretty self-evident.
We'll move to our next question, which is from the line of Mayank Bukrediwala from Goldman Sachs.
This is Rahul here.

Just, sorry for belaboring on the point, so the retail and SME slippages that we saw in this quarter, can we have a breakup, a broad breakup between how much was from, say, core retail and how much was from, say, SME?
Yes, let me give it to you, just a minute.
SME 67 and retail is some 490 or something, 491.
So out of 2,600, 491 is retail and remaining is SME.
No, no, no.
This is -- we're talking about the net slippages, Rahul.
Net slippages, 491 in retail, 67 in SME.
Can you give it on a gross basis as well, if possible?
I don't have it readily.
We don't usually share segments of a gross, (inaudible) but see, the gross thing is -- this is the reason why we don't do retail and SME on a gross and net basis.
Fundamentally, retail you do see a lot of gross and a lot of recoveries that have happened in the same quarter and, hence, the net number is always -- so this has always been the trend.
There's absolutely nothing new in this quarter.

There is one -- you heard me mention at last quarter's call that we are making a small change in the way we, kind of, recognize in the retail and the smaller ticket account that fast-forward some of the recognition processes.
You see some effect of that in the gross number in this quarter, but as you can see in the net numbers that doesn't make much of a difference.
So from the subsequent quarters, this number you think will come down to INR 800, INR 2,000 crores that you see in the previous quarter?
I think you might see -- you will see the net number fairly stable.
You're not going to see the net numbers move.
You might see the gross numbers move a little bit but you will see the net numbers pretty unchanged.
Understood.
The second question, again, on the BB & Below pool, the flow into that (inaudible) INR 5,500 crores.
Now again you made a very pertinent point about the operation going into that pool.
But same thing would have been seen, say, in the last few quarters.
So if one were to compare on a sequential basis, then how would have that number moved?
Can you give us some sense around that, please?
Only in the last two or three quarters that you've seen any upgrades at all.
So in the quarter prior, that dynamic is actually not relevant.
It's only in the last couple of quarters that it's relevant, more so in this quarter than the prior one.
Last quarter, you probably had about INR 1,500 crores, getting upgraded into BB from NPA.
This quarter you probably saw about INR 2,000 crores, INR 2,500 crores, of that nature.
In the prior quarter, you can pretty much ignore it.
It wasn't really very much.
And this is the run rate that you think we're going to, kind of, continue from.
The reason I'm asking is we've been emphasizing on this point of building a better rating -- better-rated profile kind of a corporate book.
And this number, at least on ratio terms, appear slightly at the higher end.
So (inaudible) question.
Which number is high, you think?
The slippage, the -- sorry, the movement into BB & Below, if I were to use the corporate book (inaudible)
From a BB, you mean?
So that point is pertinent.

And as I mentioned before, the movement from BBB into BB has been, on a net basis, has been, kind of, around -- kind of INR 2,500 crores range, and that is not an acceptable situation on an ongoing basis.
If it continues to be the case 3 quarters from now, that will be disappointing.
And that's why every quarter -- I mean 2 quarters ago, I said, hey, we think about the 4 quarters that's left.
Last quarter I said, hey, there's about 3 quarters left.
And this quarter I'm saying there's about a quarter or 2 left.
Of that, sort of, downward migration of ratings from -- so the story on what is the pipeline of potential downward migration of rating, that hasn't changed in the last 3 quarters.
The pipeline is reducing, but it's not down to 0 yet.
There is another quarter or 2 with that level of downward rating migration that is still left, I think.
The next question is from the line of Ravikant Bhat from Emkay Global.
I would like to first pick up from the discussion -- the risk discussion which happened on the net interest margin.
The (inaudible) has stayed quite stable quarter-on-quarter.
Now I mean in quarter maybe you have had this in stages and you did mention that there would have been (inaudible) on account of the high slippages that you have recognized.
Despite that, you are maintaining stable -- it's just about down a basis point, it is a bit perplexing.
So I mean what other factor and mix of slippages, what would have really contributed to the stability?
Because in the previous quarters when we have had slippages, I think (inaudible) was actually declining quite rapidly.
There are 2 elements to keep in mind here.
One is the fact that there are slippages, proportionately more slippages -- compared to the proportion in the portfolio, there have been more slippages in the overseas book.
So you see the overseas margins actually compress meaningfully.
So that does reflect that.
The other dynamic to keep in mind is, compared to Q3, we have a full quarter benefit of the capital rates in the quarter.
Got it.
What would have been the slippages in the overseas book, if you can share that?
We don't share that on a global -- on an overseas or a domestic basis, unfortunately.
Sorry.
No worries.
My second question is on the management change, which has been triggered by the regulators, one was what has been reported in the media.
Now I mean -- and I guess this is -- or will depend in terms wherein the regulator has been at a disadvantage with the bank, the previous one (inaudible) average in terms of the asset quality.
So I mean, I think it would help if you could just briefly let us know what exactly was the discord on -- disagreement that the regulators had?
And you have a fairly strong bench stack, why was not that -- is there no candidate considered for the post of CEO?
Why won't your -- [longest], 6-month kind of search for a new CEO from somewhere else?
See, the second part of your question, unfortunately, we cannot answer.
We are not -- it is not appropriate for management to take that question.
It is -- I think it is absolutely appropriate for the Board to look at the entire talent landscape to figure out future leaders.
So I mean, it is the Board's prerogative to look at a broad spectrum.
And this is not for us, the Executive team, to comment on that.

As far as your first question is concerned, in terms of regulatory conversations, see, any specific communication that the regulator might have had with the bank in this regard is privileged information.
This is important for us to talk about it.

But broadly speaking, Shikha's been here for 9 years, and, I mean, there was -- I mean, there was a chance that Shikha would stay for a little bit longer, she went ahead and requested for that time to be curtailed, for -- and that was accepted, and that's that.
I don't necessarily want to go into the details of why that might be, et cetera.
We are moving on as an organization.
We are -- we have, as you say, the management team, the employee base, the customer franchise, to have a successful business going forward, which is independent of any individual.

And what we are trying to articulate in our strategy presentation for FY'19 is that we also have a fairly clear strategy of what we are planning to execute on in FY '19 irrespective of what happens in the corner office.
The next question is from the line of Manish Ostwal from Nirmal Bang.

My question was on the overall credit cost you talked about in last year, the beginning of year FY'18, the great (inaudible) cost there, it was 2 to 2.5 -- the overall credit cost for the full year it has worked out (inaudible).
Now we know in this quarter you have taken a slip -- included the slippages.
Now when you say this normalization of credit cost in the first half will continue, and they will be there.
So in terms of normalization, it would be sent -- I mean the provision will be very heavy in the first half and there will be a sharp decline.
How it works?

(inaudible) quarter credit cost guidance, but the reason why we have been reticent about actually talking about that -- any earlier versions of normalcy is that one doesn't know exactly how the IBC process was going to play out and how the evolution cycles are actually going to happen and how long they're going to take.
But if your implied question is A, is there sort of any more, sort of, "deep" recognition exercise that's going to happen in the first quarter, the answer is no.
That is not -- I mean from a recognition perspective, whatever we saw and what we think needs to be done is done in this quarter.
We will see -- but we are not, at this point of time, guiding to the sort of, immediate evolution to sort of long-term business as usual.
We think it will take a couple of quarters.
We will see how it goes.
And secondly, what kind of corporate loan book growth we are looking in FY '19?
We'll see.
There're a lot of opportunities right now.
At an overall level, we are looking at high teens to 20% kind of loan growth.
And we think a lot of that is -- a lot of corporate opportunities exists right now.
Sir, because some of your peers are growing very aggressively, corporate loan book growth, so from the expenses, whether it will be growing 20% kind of the (inaudible) base or it will be much lower?
We don't have a growth target, as I mentioned during my opening comments.
From a book shaping perspective, we wanted a particular kind of balance in the book, we already achieved that.
At this point of time, there is no grand design in terms of what we want the overall, kind of, the proportion of book to be going forward.
At this point of time, it's not going to be about where the right [channel] is.
Whichever segment we see the right channel for opportunity we will go forward, whether it's retail or SME or corporate.
(Operator Instructions) We'll move to our next question, which is from the line of (inaudible) from (inaudible).
Going back to India (inaudible) you've mentioned the gross NPA movement there.
So can you tell me exact amount coming from the NPA asset upgrading to BB, and the grade from BBB to BB?
What is the...
We are talking about INR 2,500 crores.
Right.
And from BBB to BB is how much?
We also said it's roughly the same amount.
(inaudible) is the same amount, yes.
The next question is from the line of Rakesh Kumar from Elara Capital.

Just looking at your long-term trend in the margin or maybe the credit, what we have seen is that since FY '11, we always had rising margin and rising credit, even though there was pressure building on the credit quality side.
So it's very contradictory that -- or maybe we are building more risk on the book -- on the other side of the book.
And still we are, for the next year, we are, again, guiding for the stable margin.
So could you just elaborate on this issue?
I'm not sure I understood the question, to be honest.
See, the way we see it, as credit quality gets better, the proportion of your book that is noninterest earning will reduce and that should expand your margins.
Also, as the rate environment -- if it's on an upward trajectory over the course of the next year, your margins should have an expansive trend.
As you've seen, about 50% of our book is now in MCLR and our MCLR has been going upward.
So all that is margin expansive influences.
But as we move the corporate lending book more and more towards better-rated clients, that will have a margin compressive effect.
The net of this is what you will see in the overall margin trends, which we are broadly guiding for stability in the next year.
We understand.
But the thing is that since FY '11 if you see, like, maybe FY '15 or so, the gross NPA number rose from 1.1% to 5% kind of a number.
But still, the creditor number is rising.
So again, we are seeing for the next year that you will maintain the margin.
So are we building some risk on the other side of the book?
That is my limited question.
You said other side, what -- which other side you mean?
Maybe on the retail side.
Are we not building on more risk on the retail side.
That is what I want to understand.
The short answer is no.
I mean, I don't think I'm fully understanding the matter, where you're coming from.
But essentially, remember, importantly, that the gross NPA metrics that you're looking at doesn't impact margin.
The net NPA metric impacts margin.
And the net NPA metric has increased, but it is still only 2.3%.
So it's not -- sorry, 3.4%.
So it's not increased sort of to a level where it will start having that big, sort of, visual impact on margins.
And that has happened, and the reason why net NPA metric hasn't risen as much is because we are paying for the increase in NPA ratios every quarter by making -- keeping high provision coverage ratio.
So the higher you keep your PCR, the lower will be the impact of credit risk on margins.
And because we have kept PCR very high, you don't see the margin get impacted as much, even as gross NPA ratios go up.
Just one more question.
On the second half, we have guided for close to 110 or 100 bps of the credit cost.
What would be that number in the first half?
We are not guiding on what is the effect of the second half credit cost.
I think, moderator, we're pretty much out of time.
If you'll...
Sir, would you like to add any concluding remarks?
I think -- I think i will thank everyone for very active participation in this quarterly discussion.
I hope you have a very nice evening.
On behalf of Axis Bank, that concludes the conference call.
